etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Stocker (fl. 1563–1593), translator. From impertinent: see -ency

notes.text: Now rare. Impertinence is now the usual term

definitions: The fact or quality of not relating to the matter in hand; irrelevance; = "impertinence". Chiefly Law after 18th century.
An incongruity; an absurdity; a triviality; = "impertinence".
Presumptuous speech or behaviour; insolence, disrespect; = "impertinence". Now chiefly archaic.
A presumptuous, insolent, or disrespectful act or remark.
